2992.64.text: So deep learning, these deep neural network architectures is representation learning.

3000.86.text: This is the difference between traditional machine learning methods where,

3009.34.text: for example, for the task of having an image here is the input.

3014.80.text: The input to the network here is on the bottom, the output up on top,

3019.08.text: and the input is a single image of a person in this case.

3026.84.text: And so the input, specifically, is all the pixels in that image.

3033.90.text: RGB, the different colors of the pixels in the image.

3038.74.text: And over time, what a network does is build a multiverse solutional representation of this data.

3048.58.text: The first layer learns the concept of edges, for example.

3056.14.text: The second layer starts to learn composition of those edges, corners, contours.

3062.14.text: Then it starts to learn about object parts.

3066.62.text: And finally, actually provide a label for the entities that are in the input.

3074.24.text: And this is the difference in traditional machine learning methods

3077.20.text: where the concepts like edges and corners and contours

3083.04.text: are manually pre-specified by human beings, human experts, for that particular domain.

3095.40.text: And representation matters because figuring out a line

3103.64.text: for the Cartesian coordinates of this particular data set

3107.06.text: where you want to design a machine learning system

3109.78.text: that tells the difference between green triangles and blue circles is difficult.

3115.62.text: There is no line that separates them cleanly.

3120.00.text: And if you were to ask a human being, a human expert in the field.

3124.38.text: to try to draw that line they would probably do a Ph. D. on it and still not succeed.

3133.90.text: But a neural network can automatically figure out

3138.40.text: to remap that input into polar coordinates

3143.46.text: where the representation is such that it's an easily, linearly separable data set.

3152.60.text: And so, deep learning is a subset of representation learning,

3157.00.text: is a subset of machine learning and a key subset artificial intelligence.

3168.72.text: because of its ability to compute an arbitrary number of features

3174.20.text: that are at the core of the representation.

3177.16.text: So if you are trying to detect a cat in an image,

3180.60.text: you're not specifying 215 specific features of cat ears and whiskers and so on

3188.56.text: that a human expert will specify you allow and you'll know

3192.06.text: it discover tens of thousands of such features,

3195.46.text: which maybe for cats you are an expert

3197.88.text: but for a lot of objects you may never be able to sufficiently provide the features

3204.96.text: which successfully will be used for identifying the object.

3208.44.text: And so, this kind of representation learning,

3211.24.text: one is easy in the sense that all you have to provide is inputs and outputs.

3216.32.text: All you need to provide is a data set the care about without [00:53:39] features.

3221.96.text: And two, because of it's ability to construct arbitrarily sized representations,

3230.20.text: deep neural networks are hungry for data.

3232.78.text: The more data we give them,

3235.56.text: the more they are able to learn about this particular data set.

4487.82.text: So in our evaluation of what is difficult about driving,

4490.74.text: we have to remember that some of those things we may take for granted

4495.92.text: in the same kind of way that we take walking for granted, this is more of X paradox.

4506.34.text: Will Hans Moravec from CMU, let me just quickly read that quote:

4511.28.text: "Encoded in the large highly evolved sensory motor portions of the human brain

4515.42.text: is billions of years of experience about the nature of the world and how to survive in it."

4520.96.text: So this is data.  This is big data.  Billions of years and abstract thought which is reasoning.

4529.18.text: The stuff we think is intelligence is perhaps

4532.60.text: less than one hundred thousand years of data old.

4537.84.text: We haven't yet mastered it and so,

4540.64.text: I'm sorry I'm asserting my own statements in the middle of a quote,

4546.52.text: but it's been very recent that we've learned how to think.

4552.84.text: And so we respected perhaps more than the things we take for granted

4557.76.text: like walking, the visual perception and so on but those may be strictly a matter of data,

4565.08.text: data and training time and network size.

4578.18.text: The question is how hard is driving?

4581.16.text: And that's an important question because the margin of error is small.

4587.76.text: One, there's 1 fatality per 100 million miles.

4595.04.text: That's the number of people that die in car crashes every year,

4602.26.text: That's a point 0.000001% margin of error.

4607.78.text: That's through all the time you spend on the road, that is the error you get.

4612.84.text: More impressed with ImageNet being able to classify a leopard, a cat or a dog

4619.94.text: at above human level performance but this is the margin of error we get with driving.

4625.62.text: And we have to be able to deal with snow, with heavy rain, with big open parking lots,

4632.06.text: with parking garages, any pedestrians that behaves irresponsibly as rarely as that happens

4639.26.text: or just some predictably, again especially in Boston, reflections.

4649.96.text: the lighting variations that blind the cameras.

4661.76.text: The question was if that number changes, if you look at just crashes, the fatalities per crash.

4671.72.text: So one of the big things is that cars have gotten really good at crashing and not hurting anybody.

4700.92.text: is quite open about their performance since hitting public road,

4709.20.text: this is from a report that shows the number of times

4721.04.text: that it asked the driver to take control back

4723.18.text: or the driver takes control back by force.

4730.26.text: or it was putting the car or other pedestrians or other cars in unsafe situations.

4735.08.text: And so, if you see over time there's been a total

4743.76.text: there's been a total of 341 times on beautiful San Francisco roads

4749.18.text: and I say that seriously because the weather conditions are great there,

4761.82.text: And let me give you something to think about here.

4765.98.text: This, with neural networks is a big open question.

4775.04.text: So this is an amazing paper, I encourage people to read it.

4778.38.text: There's a couple of papers around this topic.

4781.44.text: Deep neural networks are easily fooled.

4785.28.text: So here are 8 images where, if given to a neural network as input,

4792.82.text: a convolutional  neural network as input, the network with higher than 99.6% confidence says

4801.18.text: that the image, for example the top left, as a robin.

4804.70.text: Next to is a cheetah, then an armadillo, a panda, an electric guitar,

4810.50.text: a baseball, a starfish, a king penguin.

4813.22.text: All of these things are obviously not in the images.

4816.92.text: So the networks can be fooled with noise.

4821.68.text: More importantly, practically for the real world, adding just a little bit of distortion,

4829.22.text: a little bit of noise distortion to the image, can force the network to produce a totally wrong prediction.

4837.84.text: So here's an example, there's 3 columns,

4842.44.text: correct image classification, the slight addition of distortion

4848.72.text: and the resulting prediction of an ostrich for all three images on the left

4854.52.text: and a prediction of an ostrich for all three images on the right.

4860.08.text: This ability to fool networks easily brings up an important point.

4866.54.text: And that point is that there has been a lot of excitement

4875.26.text: about neural networks throughout their history.

4877.74.text: There's been a lot of excitement about artificial intelligence throughout its history

4881.84.text: and not coupling that excitement, not granting that excitement, in the reality

4888.92.text: the real challenges around that has resulted in in crashes, in A.I. winters when funding dried out

4900.34.text: and people became hopeless in terms of the possibilities of artificial intelligence.

4905.36.text: So here is the 1958 New York Times article that said the Navy revealed the embryo of an electronic computer today.

4912.32.text: This is when the first perceptron that I talked about

4915.90.text: was implemented in hardware by Frank Rosenblatt.

4920.06.text: It took 400 pixel image input and it provided a single output.

4926.02.text: Weights were encoded in the hardware potentiometers

4930.32.text: and waves were updated with electric motors.

4932.92.text: Now New York Times wrote, the Navy revealed the embryo vanilla electronic computer today

4937.98.text: that expects will be able to walk, talk, see, write, reproduce itself and be conscious of its existence.

4948.48.text: Dr. Frank Rosenblatt, a research psychologist at the Cornell Aeronautical Laboratory in Buffalo,

4954.70.text: said perceptrons might be fired to the planets as mechanical space explorers.

4960.86.text: This might seem ridiculous but this is the general opinion of the time.

4967.80.text: And as we know now, perceptrons cannot even separate a non-linear function.

4978.10.text: And so this led to 2 major A.I. winters in the 70s, in the late 80s and early 90s.

4988.06.text: The Lighthill Report, in 1973 by the UK government, said there are no part of the field

4995.62.text: of discoveries made so far produced the major impact that was promised.

4999.92.text: So if the hype builds beyond the capabilities of our research,

5008.38.text: reports like this will come and they have the possibility of creating another A.I. winter.

5015.58.text: So I want to pare the optimism, some of the cool things we'll talk about in this class,

5021.36.text: with the reality of the challenges ahead of us.

5097.60.text: from some of the more interesting parts of deep learning.

5113.70.text: because it's shown in so many sort of business type lectures,

5116.68.text: but it is true that we're at the peak of a hype cycle

5120.94.text: and we have to make sure be given the large amount of hype and excited there is,

5136.02.text: One example of that, let me mention, is we already talked about spoofing the cameras.

5145.92.text: Spoofing the cameras with a little bit of noise.

5147.74.text: So if you think about it, self-driving vehicles operate with a set of sensors

5154.04.text: and they rely on those sensors to convey to accurately capture that information.

5159.04.text: And what happens, not only when the world itself produces noisy visual information,

5167.06.text: but what if somebody actually tries to spoof that data.

5171.02.text: One of the fascinating things have been recently done is spoofing of LIDAR.

5176.10.text: So these LIDAR is a range sense that gives a 3D-point cloud of the objects in the external environment.

5183.82.text: And you're able to successfully do a replay attack where you have the car

5190.76.text: see people in other cars around it when there's actually nothing around it.

5196.04.text: In the same way that you can spoof a camera to see things that are not there.
